content: I saw this on April's Fools' Day, but I only decided to post it now when I had more time. As if a written note can compensate a family's loss. ++http://www.txcn.com/sharedcontent/dws/txcn/houston/stories/khou090331_tnt_hit-and-run.8ba2ee9e.html quote: Written apology found beside body of hit-and-run victim 09:48 AM CDT on Wednesday, April 1, 2009 By Rhiannon Meyers / The Daily News & Allison Triarsi / 11 News LEAGUE CITY, Texas — The mother of man killed in a hit-and-run Sunday said someone left a handwritten note of apology beside her son’s body. Written apology found beside body of hit-and-run victim March 31, 2009 "They said that they were sorry and that they had a family," said Roberta Jones. "But he had one. you know and he was my family." Two days after Maurice Jones was found dead in a ditch along Dickinson Avenue, police were still searching for the person responsible. They won't release many details about the note, but it contained information that leads them to believe the suspect might be a woman under age 40 with a newborn baby. "It's a pure speculation that it was a female, but the handwriting appears to be of a female origin," said Scott Saldridge with the League City Police Department. Jones, 34, was hit by a vehicle as he walked home from his night shift at a fast-food restaurant. “It’s just so much,” his mother, Roberta Jones, said. “Maurice was pretty much everything.” (...) He is survived by his daughter, Jada, 11. A funeral is scheduled for 11 a.m. Saturday at New Beginnings Church, 1950 state Highway 3 in League City...

content: Had a guy over here here pull on the side off the interstate to check something on his car, got out and a pickup truck killed him. The driver never stopped or nothing. Still no leads, they do have the trucks mirror that was broken off, but no VIN on it or anything. It's like some people have resorted to human deaths no different to hitting an animal...very sad.

content: Several years ago a fire fighter was telling me how easy it was for him to spot an arsonist. I was startled and wondered how he could claim such a thing. He explained to me a series of characteristics he had recognized over his many years of service. I thanked him, but was unsure if those indicators were transferrable to criminal incidents until I was handling a fatal, pedestrian, crash where the driver fled the scene. The exact image of what my friend explained walked out from a line of trees. I wondered where is he walking from. He fit every pattern the F/F said. The guy walked up sheepishly and tried to resemble a normally-concerned citizen. His facial expressions showed fear and at first he wouldn't look me in the eye. Later he tried to become overly helpful. This behavior made me realize he was somebody who knew more than what he was saying. A walk back through the trees discovered his damaged truck and made me know he was a suspect. Later he admitted all but still brought us to a 9 day trial. He spent the next 4 yrs in prison. I think he would've been caught anyway, but it was the fire fighter who introduced me to recognizing this form of body language. I'm delighted knowing the victim's family got closure and it's made me a better teacher to new cops.
